title: How to Create a Home Photo Studio for Less

steps.headline: Locate a portable table top that can be used as a place to anchor your camera.
steps.description: When using something like this, it is a good idea to use a remote or an automatic timer. That way you will get less movement.

steps.headline: Set your studio close to a large window or a glass door for natural lighting.
Do not depend on your camera's built in flash, which will create a harsh light.
Use various types of home lighting setups like floor lamps, swing arm lamps, etc.
Optimally, find an unused corner to set it up for photographs.
You will want to watch out for shadows created by your lighting.
Be aware that the setup will change (which is the beauty of it) depending on what you are going to shoot.
Take stock of what you have at home that you can use.

steps.headline: Use your wall if it is something other than stark white.

text:
Tripods and Supports Have a tripod.  Locate a portable table top that can be used as a place to anchor your camera. When using something like this, it is a good idea to use a remote or an automatic timer. That way you will get less movement. Lighting Set your studio close to a large window or a glass door for natural lighting.  Do not depend on your camera's built in flash, which will create a harsh light.  Use various types of home lighting setups like floor lamps, swing arm lamps, etc.  Studio Optimally, find an unused corner to set it up for photographs.  You will want to watch out for shadows created by your lighting.  Be aware that the setup will change (which is the beauty of it) depending on what you are going to shoot.  Surfaces Take stock of what you have at home that you can use. Dining room table
Extra coffee or end table Look at it with an eye to what it can be used for in your studio. The table with a tablecloth on it
Your furniture, like ottomans, reclining chairs, etc Try your pet furniture. Your kitty condo (providing that it isn't too big) would work wonderfully. Backdrops Check out your linen closet for the presence of any 'backdrops' . Sheets will never work, because there any wrinkles will show, and so will the weave of the sheets. But a blanket might work nicely. Use your wall if it is something other than stark white.  Know that there are different types of 'setups'. Macro photography
Pet Photography
Portraiture Take a sheet of large paper or polypropylene, tape it to a box, and put what you are wanting to photograph on it. (This works best for 'still life' photography.
